parts: Identify that unit, the only SI unit which is still defined by an artifact rather than a replicable physical property. In 1795, one thousandth of this unit was defined as the mass of one cubic centimeter of water at 0° Centigrade.
This instrument may one day be able to define the kilogram based on electronic units. It was an improvement from the Ampere balance, and it is based upon a proposal by B. P. Kibble.

In addition to current, watt balances use this property to measure mass. The name “watt balance” comes from the fact that the measured mass is proportional to the product of current and this quantity.

answers: Queen Margaret I [accept Margrethe I; prompt on Margaret] <LT>
parts: Name this Scandinavian nation located primarily on the Jutland peninsula. Its capital is Copenhagen.
This union of Denmark, Norway, and Sweden lasted from 1397 to 1523, and notably vied with the Hanseatic League for regional supremacy.

This Danish queen founded the Kalmar Union by acquiring control of Norway and Sweden. Albert of Mecklenburg was a notable rival of hers, and the current queen of Denmark has stated that her decision to be known as “the second” is meant to recognize this ruler.

answers: Oedipus Rex [accept Oedipus Tyrannus; accept Oedipus the King; prompt on Oedipus; do not accept or prompt on “Oedipus at Colonus”]
parts: Identify this tragedy in which the title character blinds himself after learning he fulfilled a prophecy by sleeping with his mother and killing his father. At the end of this play, the chorus says to “Look upon that last day always.”
Oedipus Rex and the two plays which follow it among the Theban plays, Oedipus at Colonus and Antigone, are works by this Greek tragedian. There are a total of seven extant tragedies by this writer.

Sophocles also wrote this play about Odysseus’ attempts to win the services of an archer with an injured foot, which is set in Lemnos. It ends with a deus ex machina, as Heracles appears and promises to cure the title character.

answers: Treaty of Utrecht or Treaty of Rastatt [accept either underlined portion] <LT>
parts: Name this 1702 to 1715 conflict over who would rule an Iberian nation. It included battles like Blenheim in Europe and extensive military actions in the belligerent nations’ colonial possessions.

This British queen for much of the war is the namesake of both the North American portion of the war and a style of furniture. This female monarch oversaw the 1707 Act of Union and was the last Stuart ruler of the British isles.

Name either of the two treaties that ended the War of the Spanish Succession. In these treaties, Great Britain received Minorca but the Asiento monopoly, while the Austrians received many of Spain’s continental possessions outside of Iberia.
Name this lower part of the uterus that functions as a connection between the main part of the uterus and the vagina. Its namesake canal is the primary conduit for sperm.
This substance is used to approximate whether or not a woman is ovulating in the Billings Method. During pregnancy, a plug composed of this substance forms.
A pregnancy is terminated and a fetus’ life ends in this type of medical procedure. Some late-term varieties of this procedure involve cervical dilation.

answers: chimpanzees [prompt on apes; do not accept “monkeys”]
parts: Name this British researcher whose work challenged the long-standing notion that only humans made and used tools.
The subjects of Goodall’s research were these primates. She observed that they would often hunt and eat smaller colobus monkeys.
Goodall performed her research primarily at Gombe Stream National Park in this Eastern African nation, which contains the city of Dar es Salaam.

answers: Thus Spoke Zarathustra [or Thus Spake Zarathustra; accept Also Sprach Zarathustra]
parts: Name this mustachioed German philosopher who famously proclaimed “God is Dead.”
This book contains the famous quote “God is Dead” and details the travelings of a title character who shares a name with a crucial figure of Zoroastrianism. It is subtitled “A Book for All and None.”

[10] In Thus Spoke Zarathustra, this crucial German concept details the idea of a superior man who is seen as the goal for humanity. This specific German word is often translated as “superman”, and it became an important concept in anarchist and fascist thought.
The Pampas, known for their cowboys called gauchos, are in Uruguay, Brazil, and this country. This country’s capital of Buenos Aires lies in the Pampas on the Rio de la Plata, across from Montevideo.

This diverse geographic region, consisting of grasslands, mountains, and deserts, also lies in Argentina and was mistakenly thought to have giants by early explorers. Shared with Chile, it takes up the southernmost triangle of South America.
This other grassland region surrounds the Orinoco River in Venezuela and Colombia. The cowboys of this region formed much of Simon Bolivar’s army in the Venezuelan War of Independence.
Name this American composer of a jazz song about a subway line in Harlem, titled “Take the A Train.”

This NYC-based jazz musician and his band popularized “Take the A Train” in the 1940s, in addition to several other collaborations with Billy Strayhorn. This pianist also composed “It Don’t Mean a Thing (If It Ain’t Got That Swing).”

In the opening song of this musical, the protagonist Usnavi modifies the original jazz lyrics by singing “you must take the A train / Even farther than Harlem to northern Manhattan.” It’s not Hamilton, but this musical was written by Hunter alum Lin-Manuel Miranda, and it is set in the title Dominican-American NYC neighborhood.

answers: Quo Vadis: A Narrative of the Time of Nero [accept Quo vadis. Powieść z czasów Nerona; grudgingly accept Where Are You Going? or Whither Goest Thou?; prompt on subtitle]
Republic of Poland [accept Congress Poland; prompt on Union of Soviet Socialist Republics or Soviet Union]
Elie Wiesel [accept Eliezer Wiesel; accept Elyezer Vizel] <CL/LT>
parts: Identify this pro-Christian novel in which Marcus Vinicius falls in love with Calina, who is usually known as Ligia. Early in this novel, Acte promises to protect Ligia from the emperor’s lust.
Quo Vadis was written by Henryk Sienkiewicz (“shi-EN-kee-wreets”), an author from this nation. Alan Furst described this country in the novel The Spies of Warsaw.
This Jewish author’s most famous work is partly set in Poland. That work is Night, and this author also wrote The Trial of God.

Alviss was killed by this Norse god. He once lost a wrestling match to a personification of Old Age, and he will kill his archenemy, the World Serpent, at Ragnarok before walking nine paces and dying.

Thor was unhappy about his daughter Thrud being promised to Alviss, so he asked Alviss questions to test his wisdom until the sun came up, which did this to the dwarf. The gaze of Medusa also performed this action.
Being a dwarf, Alviss’ homeworld would have been this dark world in Norse mythology.

Identify this novel which ends when Anne Elliot and Commander Frederick Wentworth finally renew their engagement and are wed. That engagement was originally broken due to the efforts of Sir Walter and Lady Russell.
This other novel by the author of Persuasion features the Dashwood sisters, Elinor and Marianne, who eventually marry Edward Ferrars and Colonel Brandon, respectively.
Persuasion and Sense and Sensibility are both works by this British author of Mansfield Park, Northanger Abbey, and Pride and Prejudice.

answers: United Arab Republic [accept United Arab Commonwealth] <LT>
parts: Name this North African nation that was the site of the Urabi Revolt. It is home to many pyramids.
This man led Egypt from 1956 until his 1970 death. He is famous for leading Egypt during the Six Day War and for nationalizing the Suez Canal.
One of Nasser’s pet schemes was this short-lived political union between Egypt and Syria. It ended when a 1961 military coup overthrew this government in Syria and restored the Syrian Republic.

answers: North Korea [accept Democratic People’s Republic of Korea; prompt on Korea]
missile test [accept nuclear test or ballistic missile test or any kind of descriptive answer]
parts: Name this East Asian Communist state with a capital at Pyongyang. It is currently led by Kim Jong Un.

The United Nations Security Council has condemned these specific actions undertaken by North Korea under Kim Jong Un. Most recently, North Korea claimed that one of these actions was in response to a yearly joint military exercise called “Foal Eagle.”
Missile tests are not the only thing that North Korea does that enrages the free world. This American college student has been imprisoned for over a year in North Korea for stealing a sign.

answers: The Blue Rider [or Der Blaue Reiter]
Degenerate Art Exhibition [accept Die Ausstellung Entartete Kunst] <GA>
parts: Name this early 20th century movement pioneered by a group of Russian and German visual artists who aimed to express spiritual truths in their artwork. Important members included August Macke and Franz Marc.
This artist of a painting with the same name later became a leader of The Blue Rider alongside Franz Marc. This Russian artist also created several “improvisations” and “compositions.”

Several of Kandinsky’s artworks were included in a Nazi Germany art exhibition with this title, which derided works opposed to the Nazi ideal. This exhibition also included works by Ukrainian Jewish artist Marc Chagall.
Identify this family which includes Lena, Beneatha, Walter, Ruth, and Travis, all of whom live in a small South Side apartment in Chicago before moving to an all-white neighborhood.
The Youngers must decide what to do with a ten thousand dollar life insurance check in this play. In this play, Willy and Bobo steal the money Walter plans to invest in a liquor store.
A Raisin in the Sun is a work by this American playwright behind The Drinking Gourd and The Sign in Sidney Brustein’s Window.
Name these natural numbers that are neither abundant nor deficient.
This man found a formula generating all even perfect numbers using Mersenne primes. He is more famous for writing Elements, a text on geometry.
All known perfect numbers are also these numbers, which form the third diagonal in Pascal’s triangle. The square root of the sum of the first n cubic numbers is the nth one of these numbers.

answers: The “Unfinished” Symphony [or Unvollendete; accept Franz Schubert’s Symphony No. 8 in B minor; prompt on Schubert’s 8th; prompt on Symphony No. 8; prompt on clear knowledge equivalents]
parts: Name this orchestral work whose original composer died before completing its third movement.
The Unfinished Symphony was written by this composer of Winterreise. He also wrote the lied (“LEED”) Gretchen at the Spinning Wheel as well as the Trout Quintet.
Schubert also composed eight of these solo piano pieces one year prior to his death. Chopin composed a “Fantaisie” one of these in 1834.

answers: William Jefferson “Bill” Clinton [accept William Jefferson Blythe III]
parts: Name this scandal-ridden US President who was in office from 1993-2001. Formerly, he had served as the Governor of Arkansas, and his wife, Hillary, lost the 2016 US Presidential Election.

Bill Clinton lied about having sexual relations with this White House intern under oath, leading Congress to impeach Clinton. A blue dress belong to this woman was a notable piece of evidence during Clinton’s trial in the Senate.

This other Clinton-related scandal involved a failed land development deal in Arkansas in the 1970s and 1980s. Bill Clinton pardoned one of the primary actors in this scandal, Susan McDougal, right before he left office.

answers: ytterbium, yttrium, terbium, erbium [accept any underlined portion]
gadolinite [do not accept or prompt on “gadolinium”]
parts: Name any one of those four elements.
Name this mineral, the source of several rare earth elements, including ytterbium, yttrium, terbium, and erbium. It was named for a Finnish mineralogist.
This group of the periodic table, also called the rare earths, contains ytterbium, terbium, and erbium. This group is very similar to the actinides, which are one period below it.

answers: waving a handkerchief [accept variants, such as waving a cloth; accept just waving; prompt on signaling or other non-specific actions]

The Charging Chasseur [accept An Officer of the Imperial Horse Guards Charging; accept Officer of the Chasseurs Commanding a Charge; accept Officier de chasseurs à cheval de la garde impériale chargeant] <GA>
parts: Name this action which is performed by an African member of the crew of the namesake ship in The Raft of the Medusa. This action is performed due to the sighting of the Argus, which did not ultimately rescue the sinking ship.
Raft of the Medusa was the masterpiece of this French artist, who frequently used corpses as models.
In this other painting by Géricault, a horse rears amongst a scene of carnage during a battle. The horse’s rider is a cavalry officer whose hat is several times the size of his head.
